caption: Map showing the climatology of near-surface air temperature (Ta) from ERA5 for the period 1991–2020. Values are expressed in Kelvin (K). The pattern illustrates the familiar latitudinal gradient, with warmer temperatures in the tropics and cooler temperatures toward the poles.

Map illustrating the climatology of latent temperature (Tq), defined as the difference between equivalent temperature (Teq) and air temperature (Ta), based on ERA5 data for 1991–2020. Tq highlights the contribution of latent heat, with strongest values in tropical regions due to high humidity and moisture content.

Climatological map of equivalent temperature (Teq) from ERA5 for the years 1991–2020. Teq combines sensible and latent heat to represent the total thermal energy content of the near-surface atmosphere, providing a more complete picture of atmospheric heating than Ta alone.

Map of 2023 warm-season LSWT anomalies in Europe relative to the 1995–2020 baseline. Most lakes (268 analyzed) show positive anomalies, with an average trend of +0.31 ± 0.03 °C per decade. High LSWT values are consistent with increased air temperatures in the region.

Map of 2023 LSWT anomalies across African lakes. Of the 145 non-dry lakes studied, 81% showed positive anomalies, with a regional mean of +0.33 °C. Grey areas indicate regions with missing satellite data due to persistent cloud cover or other limitations.

Map showing LSWT anomalies for 496 Canadian lakes in 2023. A strong warming signal is visible, with 92% of observed lakes recording positive anomalies and a regional average anomaly of +0.83 °C. The mean warming trend since 1995 is +0.18 ± 0.03 °C per decade.

Map depicting LSWT anomalies in 144 Tibetan lakes during 2023. Around 70% of the lakes show warming, with a modest mean anomaly of +0.09 °C. Despite the smaller magnitude, this region remains sensitive to climatic shifts due to its high-altitude environment.

Lake temperature anomalies (°C, colored dots) and 2-m air temperature anomalies (°C) in 2023 for lakes in (a) Europe, (b) Africa, (c) Canada, and (d) the Tibetan Plateau. These values were calculated for the warm season (Jul–Sep in the extratropical Northern Hemisphere; Jan–Mar in the extratropical Southern Hemisphere; Jan–Dec in the tropics) with reference to the 1995–2020 base period.

Surface air temperature anomalies (°C) for the Northern Hemisphere cold season (November 2022–April 2023) relative to the 1991–2020 baseline, based on NASA GISS GISTEMP analysis. Data are used in assessing lake ice phenology metrics, including freeze and thaw timing, and ice duration across 157 lakes.

(a) Annual mean sea-surface temperature anomalies (SSTAs) in 2023 (°C) and (b) difference of annual mean SSTAs from the previous year (2023 minus 2022; °C). SSTAs are based on the 1991–2020 climatologies. The stippled areas in panel (b) indicate that the 2023-minus-2022 SSTA difference is significant at 95% confidence.

Sea surface temperature anomalies (SSTAs) during boreal winter 2022/23. The tropical Pacific shows negative SSTAs (−1.0°C to −0.2°C), reflecting La Niña conditions. Negative SSTAs are also observed in the South Pacific and Southern Ocean, while the North Pacific and Atlantic exhibit positive anomalies.

SSTAs for boreal spring 2023 show the emergence of strong coastal El Niño conditions off South America with SSTAs exceeding +1.0°C to +2.0°C. These warming events signal a transition from La Niña to El Niño. The North Pacific remains largely warm, with some coastal cooling.

In boreal summer, El Niño conditions become established, with positive SSTAs expanding westward in the tropical Pacific. SSTAs > +1.0°C dominate much of the basin. The North Atlantic also shows extensive warming, contributing to record-breaking SSTs during this period.

In boreal summer, El Niño conditions become established, with positive SSTAs By boreal autumn, El Niño has strengthened further, with widespread SSTAs > +1.0°C across the equatorial Pacific. The North Atlantic continues to experience strong warming, and the Indian Ocean shows a strong positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) signature with zonal SSTA contrast. westward in the tropical Pacific. SSTAs > +1.0°C dominate much of the basin. The North Atlantic also shows extensive warming, contributing to record-breaking SSTs during this period.

Seasonal mean sea-surface temperature anomalies (SSTAs) of ERSSTv5 (°C; shading) for (a) Dec 2022–Feb 2023, (b) Mar–May 2023, (c) Jun–Aug 2023, and (d) Sep–Nov 2023. The normalized seasonal mean SSTAs based on the seasonal mean standard deviations (SDs) over 1991–2020 are indicated by contours of −2 (dashed white), −1 (dashed black), 1 (solid black), and 2 (solid white).

Mean SSTs during (a) DJF 2022/23, (c) MAM 2023, (e) JJA 2023, and (g) SON 2023. The progression illustrates the seasonal warming of the tropical Pacific associated with the transition from a weak La Niña in DJF to a strong El Niño by SON. The black contours highlight the 30°C isotherm, showing expansion and westward shift of the warm pool. Warm SSTs exceeding 30°C expanded throughout the year, particularly evident in JJA and SON. This warming is consistent with the evolving El Niño and the development of a positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) during SON.

Mean SSTs during (a) DJF 2022/23, (c) MAM 2023, (e) JJA 2023, and (g) SON 2023. Seasonal mean sea surface temperatures (left) and anomalies (right) for DJF 2022/23 through SON 2023. DJF shows weak La Niña conditions with cooler central Pacific SSTs. A coastal El Niño emerges in MAM, expanding westward by JJA. By SON, a strong El Niño is evident with widespread warming across the equatorial Pacific. A positive Indian Ocean Dipole also develops in SON, with warm SSTs in the west and cool SSTs in the east. Black contours mark the 30°C isotherm in the left panels. progression illustrates the seasonal warming of the tropical Pacific associated with the transition from a weak La Niña in DJF to a strong El Niño by SON. The black contours highlight the 30°C isotherm, showing expansion and westward shift of the warm pool. Warm SSTs exceeding 30°C expanded throughout the year, particularly evident in JJA and SON. This warming is consistent with the evolving El Niño and the development of a positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) during SON.

Subsurface temperature anomalies show a weakening La Niña, with slightly cooler-than-average temperatures in the eastern Pacific and warm anomalies in the west. The thermocline slope was slightly steeper than average, with a deeper-than-normal thermocline in the west.
During the La Niña–El Niño transition, warm anomalies spread eastward and the thermocline deepened across the entire equatorial Pacific, indicating the early stages of El Niño development.
As El Niño strengthened, the thermocline slope flattened. Warm subsurface anomalies expanded eastward, and the thermocline in the western Pacific returned to near-average depths.
Strong El Niño conditions persisted. The thermocline deepened in the central and eastern Pacific, with widespread warm anomalies and a much shallower thermocline slope across the basin.

Time–longitude section for 2023 of the anomalous equatorial Pacific Ocean heat content, calculated as the mean temperature anomaly (°C) between 0-m and 300-m depth. Yellow/red (blue) shading indicates above- (below-) average heat content. Anomalies are departures from the 1991–2020 base period pentad means. Data in (b) are derived from an analysis system that assimilates oceanic observations into an oceanic general circulation model (Behringer et al. 1998).

Atlantic Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) position inferred from outgoing longwave radiation (Liebmann and Smith 1996) during Mar 2023. The colored thin lines indicate the approximate position for the six pentads of the month. The thick black line indicates the Atlantic ITCZ climatological position for Mar. The sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) for Mar 2023 calculated with respect to the 1982–2020 climatology are shaded. The two boxes indicate the areas used for the calculation of the Atlantic index in panel

Sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies during August–October (ASO) 2023 in the Atlantic Main Development Region (MDR). SSTs were exceptionally warm across the MDR, with area-averaged anomalies reaching +1.16 °C—setting a new record since at least 1950 by more than 0.5 °C. SST anomalies within the MDR ranged from +0.5 °C to over +1.5 °C, consistent with the warm phase of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation and indicative of an Atlantic high-activity era.

Sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) and the tracks of all 2023 storms (including tropical depressions [TDs], tropical storms [TSs], and typhoon-strength storms [Cat]), with colors denoting their intensity.

Conditions were particularly favorable during the pre-monsoon period (May–June) when two of the major cyclones occurred. Sea-surface temperatures were unusually warm across the basin, with large anomalies in the Arabian Sea.

Tracks of tropical cyclones Darian, Cheneso, Freddy, and Fabien during the 2022/23 South Indian Ocean season, overlaid on sea surface temperature anomalies (°C). Track colors indicate cyclone intensity by SSHWS category.

Global anomalies of tropical cyclone heat potential (TCHP) in 2023 (kJ cm⁻²), with green lines showing tracks of Category 1+ cyclones during the main TC seasons (Nov–Apr in the Southern Hemisphere, Jun–Nov in the Northern Hemisphere) and purple lines showing off-season storms. Boxes outline seven key TC basins, with storm counts labeled; Gulf of Mexico shown in inset.

Vertical profile of daily 40°N–80°N eddy heat flux anomalies (std. dev.; shading) and 60°N zonal-mean zonal winds (m s−1; gray contours, with the zero-wind line in black) for 30 days before to 30 days after the 16 February 2023 sudden stratospheric warming (SSW). (

Average 2-m temperature anomalies (°C, shading) and mean sea-level pressure anomalies (hPa, contours) for the 15 days prior to the SSW (1–15 February) and (c) during a period of stratosphere–troposphere coupling following the SSW (1–15 March). Data are from the ERA5 reanalysis (Hersbach et al. 2023a,b) and all anomalies are shown with respect to a 30-day centered smoothed 1991–2020 climatology. profile of daily 40°N–80°N eddy heat flux anomalies (std. dev.; shading) and 60°N zonal-mean zonal winds (m s−1; gray contours, with the zero-wind line in black) for 30 days before to 30 days after the 16 February 2023 sudden stratospheric warming (SSW). (
Warm anomalies over northern Canada and the North Atlantic; cooler conditions over Alaska and eastern Siberia.
Record warmth across the Arctic, especially northern Canada, Greenland, and the Barents–Kara Sea region.
Widespread Arctic warming continues, with some cooling over eastern Europe and western Russia.
Mean sea-surface temperature (SST; °C) in Aug 2023. Black contours indicate the 10°C-SST isotherm.

Anomalies show where sea-surface temperatures in August 2023 were warmer (red shades) or cooler (blue shades) compared to the 1991–2020 climatological average. The black line indicates the median ice edge for August 1991–2020.

Differences highlight areas where SSTs in August 2023 were either warmer or cooler than those in August 2022. White shading shows August 2023 sea-ice extent; the black line indicates the 1991–2020 median ice edge.

Sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) for June 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 June mean. White shading indicates mean sea-ice concentration for June 2023. Much of the Arctic marginal seas still had significant ice cover in June, making SST trend evaluation less appropriate for this month.

Sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) for July 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 July mean. White shading indicates mean sea-ice concentration for July 2023. Early retreat of sea ice, especially in the Beaufort Sea, corresponds to warmer SSTs via the ice–albedo feedback.

Sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) for August 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 August mean. White shading indicates mean sea-ice concentration for August 2023. SST anomalies were highest in the Barents, Kara, Laptev, and Beaufort Seas (~5–7°C above average), and lower in Baffin Bay and parts of the Chukchi and Bering Seas.

Sea-surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) for September 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 September mean. White shading shows mean sea-ice concentration for September 2023. Warm anomalies in marginal seas persisted into September, though reduced, as surface cooling began in the latter half of the month.

Linear sea-surface temperature (SST) trend (°C yr−1) for Aug of each year from 1982 to 2023. The trend is only shown for values that are statistically significant at the 95% confidence interval; the region is shaded light gray otherwise. White shading is the August 2023 mean sea-ice extent, and the black line indicates the August 1991–2020 median ice edge. (
Locations of the permafrost temperature monitoring sites superimposed on average surface air temperature trends (°C decade−1) during 1981–2023 from ERA5 reanalysis
Polar-cap averaged temperature anomalies (°C; contour interval is 0.5°C up to ±2°C and 2°C after ±2°C);
Annual average temperature anomalies (°C; 1991–2020 base period) in Canada for the period 1948–2023. The black line represents an 11-year running mean.
Annual average temperature anomalies (°C) in Canada for 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 climate normal. Warm anomalies >2.5°C occurred in much of the Northwest Territories and western Nunavut.

Annual average temperature anomalies (°C) for the contiguous United States (CONUS) in 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 climatological average. Most regions were warmer than normal, with cooler anomalies in parts of the western U.S.
Annual average temperature anomalies (°C; 1991–2020 base period) in Canada for the period 1948–2023. The black line represents an 11-year running mean.

Annual average temperature anomalies (°C) across Mexico in 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 base period. Widespread warming was observed, with central and northern regions showing anomalies above +2°C.

Annually averaged 2-m air temperature anomalies (°C) over the Caribbean for 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 average. Widespread warming was observed across the region, making 2023 the warmest year on record since 1950.

Annual 2023 temperature anomalies (°C) across South America for (a) maximum, (b) minimum, and (c) mean 2-m air temperatures, relative to the 1991–2020 average. Northern South America experienced widespread maximum temperature anomalies >+1°C, particularly in Venezuela, Suriname, Colombia, and Ecuador. Minimum temperatures showed more spatial variability, with below-normal values in Bolivia and Venezuela.

Annual mean surface air temperature anomalies (°C) across Africa for 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 average. Widespread above-average temperatures were observed across most of Africa, with anomalies exceeding +1.2°C in northwest and southwest regions.

Surface air temperature anomalies (°C) for winter (DJF 2022–2023) over North Africa. Anomalies >+2°C were observed in eastern Mauritania and parts of Mali, while Libya and parts of Egypt showed near or below-average temperatures.

Temperature anomalies (°C) for spring (MAM 2023) over North Africa. Strong warming (>+2°C) occurred across Morocco, western Algeria, and northern Mauritania, while Libya and southwestern Egypt remained near or below average.

Summer (JJA 2023) temperature anomalies (°C) over North Africa. Extreme heat >+2°C was widespread across Morocco, northern Algeria, Tunisia, Mauritania, and parts of Egypt. Some stations reported record-breaking highs.

Autumn (SON 2023) temperature anomalies (°C) over North Africa. Anomalies >+2°C dominated much of the region, especially in Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia. Libya experienced more moderate warming (+0.5°C to +1.5°C).

Annual mean temperature (°C) across West Africa in 2023. Most of the region recorded temperatures between 24°C–30°C, with the highest values across central Nigeria and coastal areas of the Gulf of Guinea.
Temperature percentile rank across West Africa in 2023. Most areas experienced temperatures in the 90th–99th percentile range, indicating near-record warmth across the region.
Annual maximum temperature anomalies (°C) over Central Africa in 2023. Anomalies of +2°C to +5.5°C were observed, especially over southern DRC and surrounding regions.
Annual minimum temperature anomalies (°C) over Central Africa in 2023. Anomalies ranged from −1.5°C to +2°C, with cooler-than-average temperatures in parts of southeastern DRC and surrounding areas.
Annual mean temperature (°C) across East Africa in 2023. Highest temperatures (30°C+) were recorded in Sudan and coastal areas, while highlands of Ethiopia remained cooler (<22°C).
Annual mean temperature anomalies (°C) across East Africa in 2023. Anomalies were generally +0.5°C to +1.5°C, with the highest over Sudan and Afar regions of Ethiopia.

Annual mean temperature anomalies (°C) in Southern Africa in 2023. Warm anomalies (+1.5°C to +2°C) were strongest over west-central Botswana, while below-average temperatures were observed in western Namibia.
Mean annual temperature anomalies (°C, squares), annual rainfall ratio to normal (%, circles), and their respective deciles for the western Indian Ocean island countries in 2023

(a) Annual mean temperature (°C) and (b) annual mean temperature anomalies (°C) in Madagascar for 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 average. Temperatures ranged from 20°C to 26°C, with warm anomalies of +0.5°C to +1°C observed across the northern and central parts of the country.

Seasonal anomalies (1991–2020 base period) of 500-hPa geopotential height (contour; m) and surface temperature (shading; °C) using data from the NCEP/NCAR reanalysis and Deutscher Wetterdienst (DWD), respectively, for (a) Dec–Feb (DJF) 2022/23, (b) Mar–May (MAM) 2023, (c) Jun–Aug (JJA) 2023, and (d) Sep–Nov (SON) 2023.

Annual mean surface temperature anomalies (°C) over Asia in 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 base period. Widespread warming was observed, with anomalies exceeding +2°C across Central Asia and Siberia.
Annual mean surface air temperature (°C) for Central Asia in 2023. Temperatures ranged from below 0°C in high-elevation eastern Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to 25°C in southern Afghanistan.

Annual mean temperature anomalies (°C) for Central Asia in 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 baseline. Anomalies reached +2.5°C to +3.0°C in western Kazakhstan and northwestern Uzbekistan, while cooler anomalies (−2.0°C to −0.5°C) were recorded in parts of eastern Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and northeastern Afghanistan.

Winter (December 2022 – February 2023) mean 2-m temperature anomalies (°C) across the Middle East and Central Asia. Temperatures were near or slightly below normal across much of Iran and Central Asia, with above-normal anomalies in southern Iran and parts of the western Middle East.
Spring (March–May 2023) temperature anomalies (°C). Significant warming observed from northern Iran through Central Asia, with anomalies reaching +2°C to +4°C in parts of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.

Summer (June–August 2023) temperature anomalies (°C). Above-normal temperatures were widespread, though less intense than spring and autumn. Iran experienced notable heat, especially in southern and central regions.

Autumn (September–November 2023) temperature anomalies (°C). Marked warming across most of the region, including Iran, with anomalies between +0.5°C and +4.5°C. November 2023 was the warmest on record in Iran in 70 years.

Mean air temperature anomalies (°C) for January 2023 in Russia, relative to the 1991–2020 average. A strong cold anomaly (−8°C to −10°C) dominated northern Eastern Siberia and western Yakutia, with extreme cold events dropping temperatures below −60°C in some locations. Widespread below-average temperatures were observed across most of Asian Russia east of 110°E

Air temperature anomalies (°C) during January–March 2023. Slightly below-normal temperatures prevailed along the equator east of the dateline due to fading La Niña conditions, while slightly above-normal temperatures were observed across Palau, western FSM, Guam, and CNMI.

Air temperature anomalies (°C) during April–June 2023. Above-normal temperatures expanded across the region, with warming increasing toward the southeast, indicating the early effects of El Niño development

Air temperature anomalies (°C) during July–September 2023. A warming trend continued across Micronesia, with moderate positive anomalies in far western and southeastern parts of the region, especially near the Marshall Islands.

Air temperature anomalies (°C) during October–December 2023. Persistent above-normal temperatures were observed, particularly southeast of the Marshall Islands, driven by strengthening El Niño conditions.

Sea Surface Temperature (SST) rankings for January–June 2023. Record-high SSTs (rank 1) were recorded west of Palau, extending northeastward toward Yap and south of Guam, consistent with early-year warming patterns.

SST rankings for July–December 2023. Record-warm SSTs in the Niño-4 region expanded northward, with high rankings (1st–3rd warmest) near the Marshall Islands. This reflects the full onset of El Niño during the second half of the year.

Map shows surface air temperature anomalies across the South Pacific. Slightly below-normal temperatures (~−1°C) are observed east of the dateline, consistent with a fading La Niña pattern. A small cool region is seen near Tonga. Temperatures are near normal elsewhere across the basin.

Warm anomalies spread along the equator towards the central Pacific, especially near the South American coast, associated with developing El Niño SST patterns. A small cooler region south of the Cook Islands remains but transitions toward normal by June.
Positive temperature anomalies (+1°C to +3°C) expand westward along the equator, reaching western Kiribati. This reflects the strengthening El Niño. Off-equatorial areas mostly remain near normal.

El Niño persists. Temperature anomalies of up to +2°C are observed across much of Kiribati. Meanwhile, cooler-than-normal temperatures (up to −1°C) emerge in off-equatorial areas east of the dateline, including Tonga, Niue, and parts of French Polynesia.
Minimum temperature anomalies (°C) for Australia, averaged over 2023, relative to a 1991–2020 base period. (Source: Australian Bureau of Meteorology.)

Annual average temperature anomaly (°C) for New Zealand in 2023, relative to the 1991–2020 base period. The black dots represent the locations of climate stations used to create the map. (Source: NIWA, New Zealand.)
Maximum temperature anomalies (°C) for Australia, averaged over 2023, relative to a 1991–2020 base period. (Source: Australian Bureau of Meteorology.)

Arctic temperature trends showing an annual surface temperature change rates across the Northern Hemisphere from 1961–1990 (Stewart et al., 1998), and temperature anomalies (55–85°N) from 1900–2002, highlighting that the high temperatures of the late 1980s–1990s were similar to those in the 1930s–1940s.

Change in surface air temperature for 2020–2030 relative to 1990–2000 as projected by the Canadian Centre for Climate Modeling and Analysis CGCM2. Global warming is expected to have an uneven geographic distribution with the Arctic experiencing the highest projected warming
Global surface temperature anomalies (°C) for 2000–2009 relative to the 1951–1980 average, showing widespread warming, particularly in the Arctic and parts of Eurasia. Global mean anomaly: +0.60°C.
Surface temperature anomalies (°C) for 2010–2019 compared to 1951–1980, highlighting intensified warming, especially in the Arctic and over land masses. Global mean anomaly: +0.81°C.
Projected surface temperature anomalies (ΔT) under the low-emissions scenario ssp119 for 2085–2100, showing spatial patterns of warming compared to preindustrial levels.
Normalized warming pattern (ΔT(r)/ΔT̄) for ssp119, showing regions where warming is above or below the global mean. Arctic amplification is prominent.
Projected surface temperature anomalies (ΔT) under the high-emissions scenario ssp585 for 2085–2100, with widespread warming especially across the Northern Hemisphere.
Normalized warming pattern for ssp585. The Arctic shows extreme warming, whereas oceans and the Southern Hemisphere show less than average warming
Surface temperature anomalies after 136–150 years of abrupt quadrupling of CO₂, with strong Arctic amplification and globally elevated temperatures.
Ratio of local to global warming (ΔT(r)/ΔT̄) under abrupt-4xCO2 conditions, highlighting enhanced polar amplification particularly in the Arctic.
Global surface temperature change (in K) in the ACE2-SOM emulator for a 3xCO₂ climate compared to 1xCO₂. The mean warming is 3.36 K globally, 4.62 K over land, and 2.84 K over ocean/sea ice regions.

Root mean square (RMS) error of surface temperature in ACE2-SOM compared to C96 SHiELD-SOM for a 3xCO₂ climate. The bias is shown at 4° resolution, with errors of 0.34 K globally, 0.45 K over land, and 0.29 K over ocean/sea ice.
Surface temperature change (K) from tripling CO₂ (3xCO₂ vs. 1xCO₂) in the physics-based C24 SHiELD-SOM model. Global mean warming is 3.29 K, with 4.65 K over land and 2.74 K over ocean/sea ice.
Surface temperature change (K) in the high-resolution C96 SHiELD-SOM for a 3xCO₂ climate. Global mean warming is 3.34 K, with a greater warming of 4.86 K over land and 2.73 K over ocean/sea ice.

Surface temperature bias (in K) between the lower-resolution C24 SHiELD-SOM and the high-resolution C96 SHiELD-SOM, under a 3xCO₂ climate. Positive values indicate regions where C24 overestimates temperature compared to C96.
Surface air temperature difference (°C) between the 4×CO₂ scenario (years 201–300) and control (years 101–1000), showing strongest warming in the Arctic due to polar amplification.

Current and projected temperature changes globally (11). The top maps show the estimated climate change for a 28C global average change; the middle figure for a 38C change and the bottom figure for a 48C change. The new unpublished maps for RCP8.5 are very similar to the bottom maps.
Annual mean temperature anomalies (measured 2 metres above the ground) in atmospheric-river events

Projected changes in mean annual temperature (°C) from 2070 to 2099 relative to 1961 to 1990, based on the SRES A2 emissions scenario. Results represent median projections from 16 global climate models, showing the greatest warming in high northern latitudes.

Predicted percent loss of amphibian species across the Western Hemisphere under future climate change scenarios. Map (A) shows projected losses in species richness, while map (B) shows projected gains. Predictions are based on ten different climate models under the A2 emissions scenario, with values reflecting areas where at least 8 out of 10 models agree. Light gray indicates regions with insufficient data for modeling.

Global distribution of drought-related research. Regions in deeper red shades represent areas with higher research density on droughts, with notable hotspots in the western United States, parts of Europe (e.g., Spain, Italy), South Korea, and Bangladesh. Some African countries like Ethiopia, Kenya, and Nigeria also show relatively high levels of drought research.

Global distribution of landslide-related research. Highest research densities are seen in the Alps, Himalayas, Central China, Taiwan, and parts of Japan. Despite high hazard exposure, many tropical and low-income regions remain underrepresented in landslide studies.

Observed trend in sea surface temperature (SST) from the Extended Reconstructed SST data set version 5 (ERSSTv5) over the period 1979–2020. Shows pronounced warming in the Indo-Pacific Warm Pool and parts of the North Atlantic and North Pacific, as well as cooling in the Southern Ocean.

Simulated SST trend over the same period from the multi-model mean of 16 climate model large ensembles. The trend has been rescaled so that the global mean matches that of ERSSTv5, highlighting spatial differences rather than mean warming.

The normalized deviation of observed SST trends from the multi-model mean, expressed in standard deviations of ensemble spread. RMSE (root mean square error) is shown at the top right. This map highlights regions where the observed trends are most anomalous.
One of the dominant spatial patterns of difference between observations and modeled SST trends. Highlights greater observed warming in the Indo-Pacific and cooling in the eastern equatorial Pacific.
Another dominant discrepancy pattern showing different spatial anomalies in SST between observations and models, particularly in the central Pacific and North Atlantic.
Annual-mean near-surface (2 m) air temperature (°C) averaged over 1980–2005 from the CMIP5 multi-model ensemble mean.
Bias in the CMIP5 multi-model ensemble mean surface temperature relative to the ERA-Interim reanalysis for 1980–2005.
Mean absolute error (°C) in surface temperature from the CMIP5 multi-model ensemble compared to ERA-Interim climatology over 1980–2005.
Root mean square error (°C) of surface temperature seasonal cycle in CMIP5 models compared to ERA-Interim data, averaged over 1980–2005.

Annual mean surface air temperature (°C) from the CMIP5 multi-model mean (1980–2005), showing general agreement with ERA-Interim, with larger biases in regions like the Himalayas and coastal upwelling zones.

Frequency of occurrence of local temperature anomalies (relative to 1951–1980 mean) divided by local standard deviation for land areas shown on map. Area under each curve is unity. Percentages indicate the fraction of the global land area covered by the region. ‘Shift’ and ‘width’ describe the Gaussian fit to the 2005–2015 distribution relative to 1951–1980.

Changes in seasonal temperature anomaly distributions for selected regions. Bell curves show the frequency of local temperature anomalies relative to 1951–1980, indicating warming trends across decades and seasons.
For lower latitude regions. Subtropical and tropical zones show stronger shifts toward higher temperatures, with most summers exceeding +2σ relative to the 1951–1980 baseline.
Map of surface air temperature anomalies for 2005–2015 relative to 1951–1980. Strongest warming appears in the Mediterranean, Middle East, Sahara, Gobi Desert, and southwestern United States.
(a) Fossil fuel CO₂ emissions by source in 2014. (b) Cumulative emissions from 1751 to 2014. Emissions are categorized by coal, oil, gas, and cement. Data from BP (2015) and Boden et al. (2015).
(a) Per capita fossil fuel CO₂ emissions in 2014. (b) Cumulative per capita emissions since 1751. Developed countries show significantly higher emissions compared to developing nations.

Observed frequency distribution of seasonal (June–August and December–February) local temperature anomalies over India and neighboring regions. Distributions show a clear shift toward warmer anomalies over time, with increasing frequency of extreme heat events relative to the 1951–1980 baseline.

Trends in near-surface air temperature (K/decade) from 1978–2018 based on HadCRUT4-CW observations (top left) and IPSL-CM6A-LR model outputs: ensemble mean (top right), four members with lowest RMSE (middle), and four with highest RMSE (bottom). RMSE values and member numbers are indicated. Model data are regridded to the observational grid.

Trends in upper ocean heat content (0–700 m, 10⁹ J m⁻² per decade) from 1978–2018 based on Cheng & Zhu (2016) observations (top left) and IPSL-CM6A-LR simulations: ensemble mean (top right), four members with lowest RMSE (middle), and highest RMSE (bottom). Model data are regridded to the observational grid.

Difference in average monthly temperature (°C) between the generated DiffESM output and a held-out ESM ensemble member (HO2, left), and between two held-out ESM ensemble members (HO1 vs. HO2, right). These comparisons assess how closely the generated data matches the target distribution and the internal variability of the Earth system model output

Winter (DJF) mean temperature across Mongolia for the period 1960–2016. The map displays colder temperatures in the northern regions and milder winters in the south, highlighting the latitudinal gradient in seasonal climate.

Spatial trend of summer (JJA) temperature from 1960 to 2016 in Mongolia. The map shows a significant warming trend across nearly all regions, with stippling indicating areas where the trend is statistically significant (p < 0.05).
Projected return periods (years) for historical 100-year floods by 2071–2100 under RCP8.5. Warmer colors indicate more frequent floods, cooler tones indicate less frequent ones.

Time-evolving surface air temperature trend from ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD), showing progressive warming from 1950 to 2009, with strongest warming in northern mid-latitudes. Panel (h) shows linear trend for comparison.
Instantaneous warming rates based on EEMD trends from 1950 to 2009. Panel (h) shows the linear warming rate. Most regions exhibit consistent warming by 1980.
Zonal mean surface temperature trend from 1901 to 2009, highlighting earlier warming in subtropical and subpolar Northern Hemisphere regions, later expanding poleward and southward.

Observed and simulated warming trends (1982–2011) over China. Panels show observed (CRU) and simulated (SCE) annual mean air temperature trends, time series of anomalies, and scatter plot comparing observations and model results.

Temporal changes in vegetation (LAI and forest area) and their effects on air temperature and energy fluxes in China (1982–2011). Includes trends in LAI, vegetation-induced temperature change, and associated changes in surface radiation and heat fluxes.
Time series and correlation between observed (CRU) and simulated (SCE) annual temperature anomalies over China (c), and their spatial correlation (d).
Vegetation-induced annual mean temperature change (°C/decade) across China (1982–2011), highlighting regions with significant cooling due to greening and afforestation.
Seasonal trends in leaf area index (LAI), surface energy components (radiation and fluxes), and vegetation-induced air temperature changes across China, with focus on spring and summer.
Trends in surface radiation and energy fluxes (1982–2011) due to vegetation change, including net radiation, shortwave and longwave radiation, and latent/sensible heat.
Springtime changes in temperature and atmospheric circulation induced by vegetation greening, showing trends in surface and upper-level temperature, geopotential height, and winds.
Relationship between LST and evapotranspiration in afforested areas, showing that increased evapotranspiration leads to surface cooling.
Relationship between LST and albedo, indicating that lower albedo due to vegetation change can offset some cooling effects, especially in darker forested regions.

Spatial distribution of all-cause disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs) per 100,000 people attributable to non-optimal temperature exposure in 2019, combining the effects of both heat and cold. Insets highlight regions with notable burdens, such as the Persian Gulf, Southeast Asia, and the Balkan Peninsula.

Global distribution of DALYs (per 100,000) attributable to high temperatures in 2019. The highest heat-related burden is observed in South and Southeast Asia, Sub-Saharan Africa, and parts of the Middle East, reflecting elevated temperature exposure and vulnerability.

Global distribution of DALYs (per 100,000) attributable to low temperatures in 2019. Cold-related health burdens dominate in Eastern Europe, Central and East Asia, and parts of South America and North America, driven mainly by cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.

Global map of average daily mean temperatures at 750 locations across 43 countries used in the analysis, color-coded by temperature range. Data represent the average conditions during the study period from 2000 to 2019.

Average annual excess deaths attributable to non-optimal temperatures between 2000 and 2019, shown at a spatial resolution of 0.5° × 0.5°. Higher densities are concentrated in Eastern and Southern Asia and parts of Europe.
Average annual excess deaths related specifically to cold temperatures from 2000 to 2019. Cold-related mortality is more spatially widespread and dominant compared to heat-related deaths.
Average annual excess deaths related to heat exposure over the 2000–2019 period. Highest burdens are observed in parts of Europe and densely populated areas of South and East Asia.

Total attributable fraction (%) of all-cause mortality related to non-optimal temperatures in 147 European regions during the observational period (1998–2012). Darker regions represent higher fractions.
Relative risk (RR) of death associated with the 99th percentile of daily temperature. Mediterranean regions show stronger heat-related mortality risk.
Attributable fraction (%) of deaths due to cold temperatures. Most regions show a larger burden from cold than heat, with relatively homogeneous spatial distribution.
Relative risk (RR) of death associated with the 1st percentile of daily temperature. Cold-related mortality risks are relatively uniform across Europe.
Attributable fraction (%) of deaths due to heat. The Mediterranean countries exhibit the highest heat-related mortality burden.

Projected anomalies in temperature-attributable mortality for the mid-21st century (2035–2064) relative to 1976–2005 under three emission scenarios (RCP2.6, RCP6.0, RCP8.5), for total, cold, and heat effects. Heat-related mortality is expected to increase, especially under RCP8.5, with significant impacts in southern Europe.

Projected change in coastline length suitable for Vibrio (km/year) under the SSP2-4.5 scenario (2015–2100). Highest projected increases in suitability are found in Finland (52 km/year), Sweden (43), and Canada (16). Source: Figure 1B, Lancet Planet Health 2021

Historical change in coastline suitable for Vibrio (km/year) during 1850–2014. Most countries showed negligible change, but Sweden and Finland had slight positive trends. Source: Figure 1A, Lancet Planet Health 2021
Historical change (1850–2014) in percentage of coastline suitable for Vibrio per year. Most areas exhibit neutral or slight decreases, with a few small increases in the Baltic region.
Projected change under SSP2-4.5 (2015–2100) in percentage of coastline suitable for Vibrio. Baltic nations such as Finland and Sweden show the most rapid expansion in suitable coastlines.
Projected change in coastline suitable for Vibrio (km/year) under SSP5-8.5 (2015–2100) scenario. Dramatic increases in Finland (101 km/year), Sweden (85), and Canada (49).
Projected change under SSP5-8.5 (2015–2100) in percentage of coastline suitable for Vibrio. Striking expansion in high-latitude regions, particularly around the Baltic Sea.
Effects of climate on labour, 1986–2005. (A) Labour supply factor, (B) labour productivity factor, and (C) effective labour factor (as a combination of A and B).
Labour supply (A), labour productivity (B), and effective labour (C) for outdoor working conditions in the shade or indoors, for 1·5°C, 2·0°C, and 3·0°C global warming.

Temperature climatology and trend patterns in the stratosphere (ERA5 vs MERRA-2). Top panels show January average temperatures (K) for the period 1980–2020 at 1, 10, 50, and 100 hPa using ERA5 and MERRA-2 datasets. Bottom panels present linear temperature trends (K per decade) for the same period. Notable differences between the two reanalyses are evident at higher altitudes (e.g., 1 hPa), while agreement improves at lower levels (e.g., 100 hPa).

Winter (DJF) temperature fields (K) for four decades—1980–1990, 1990–2000, 2000–2010, and 2010–2020—at 1, 5, 10, 30, and 100 hPa using ERA5 reanalysis. The structure shows strong inter-decadal variability, with warmer anomalies in the upper stratosphere during 2000–2010 and a cooling trend in the lower stratosphere in recent decades.

Spatial differences (K) between decadal winter (DJF) mean temperatures for pressure levels 1, 5, 10, 30, and 100 hPa, computed from ERA5. The figure highlights significant temperature changes between 1990–2000 and 2000–2010 in both hemispheres, particularly over the Northern Hemisphere high latitudes.

Climatological mean of annual 2 m air temperature and sea surface temperature from (a) observation (CRU over land and ERSST over ocean), (b–e) CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2 and ERA Interim, and (f–i) biases with respect to CRU and ERSST. Unit: °C

Climatological mean annual net shortwave radiation at the surface from (a) observation (CERES), (b–e) CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2 and ERA Interim, and (f–i) climatological biases with respect to observation. Unit: W/m²

Climatological mean annual net longwave radiation at the surface from (a) observation (CERES), (b–e) CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2 and ERA Interim, and (f–i) climatological biases with respect to observation. Unit: W/m²

Climatological mean annual cycle of (a) net shortwave radiation, (b) net longwave radiation, (c) sensible heat flux, and (d) latent heat flux at the surface from observation (CERES), CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2, and ERA Interim. Unit: W/m²

Climatological mean annual longwave radiation at the top of the atmosphere from (a) observation (CERES), (b–e) CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2 and ERA Interim, and (f–i) climatological biases with respect to observation. Unit: W/m²
Climatological mean annual cycle of (a) net shortwave radiation and (b) longwave radiation at the top of the atmosphere from observation (CERES), CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2, and ERA Interim. Unit: W/m²
Climatological mean annual albedo at the surface from (a) observation (CERES), (b–e) CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2 and ERA Interim, and (f–i) climatological biases (%) with respect to observation
Monthly climatological biases in CFSv2 all-sky albedo (%) with respect to observation (CERES). The green contour represents the 5 cm snow depth in CFSv2

Statistics on global annual mean downward shortwave radiation (SW down), upward shortwave radiation (SW up), net shortwave (Net SW), downward longwave radiation (LW down), upward longwave radiation (LW up), net longwave (Net LW), sensible heat flux (SHF), latent heat flux (LHF), ground heat flux (GHF), and imbalance at the surface from observation (CERES), CFSv2, CFSR, NCEP2, and ERA Interim. Unit: W/m²
Linear trend of annual surface air temperature (units: °C ­ decade−1) during 1961–2014. The dotted regions represent correla- tions required for significance at the 95% level.
Absolute trends in annual maximum daily discharge in the time period 1971–2010

Regional classification of global river basins by discharge trends. The map divides the world into nine major geographic regions based on hydrological and socio-economic characteristics. Each region is further split into subregions with either increasing (R⁺, darker shades) or decreasing (R⁻, lighter shades) discharge trends, as observed between 1971 and 2010.

The map shows subnational GDP losses across Europe due to heatwave-induced labor productivity decline in 2018. Southern regions, particularly in Spain, France, and Italy, experienced the most severe impacts, with losses exceeding 2.5% of regional GDP in some areas.

This map illustrates the spatial distribution of GDP impacts from the 2010 summer heatwave. Notable losses are concentrated in southern and eastern Europe, including parts of Greece, Bulgaria, and southern Spain.

The 2003 heatwave led to widespread economic disruption across Europe. Southern and central regions, especially France, Italy, and the Balkans, show some of the highest heat-related productivity losses observed in the study.
Subnational GDP losses were again prominent in southern Europe, with intensified effects observed in Spain, Italy, and the Balkans, reflecting repeated vulnerability to extreme summer heat.

Each panel shows the estimated regional GDP loss (%) from heatwave-induced labor productivity declines in the years 2003, 2010, 2015, and 2018. The maps highlight both the recurrence of losses in southern Europe and the gradual expansion of impacts northward over time.

Schematic of the study’s modeling approach. Green and blue boxes represent models and data, respectively. Observations drive Earth system model (ESM) simulations, which are then used to train emulator models to predict regional climate responses across time and emissions scenarios.

Comparison of observed and emulated regional temperature anomalies (2001–2020). Emulators are trained on individual ESMs and CMIP6 multi-model means. Panels show observed vs. emulated temperature trends for each land region.

Comparison of emulator-predicted and observed precipitation anomalies. Similar to Fig. 2 but for precipitation. Results demonstrate good agreement across most land regions, with some variation in tropics.
Regional temperature projections under SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios. Panels show the ensemble mean and 90% confidence intervals of emulated regional warming across SSPs and decades.
Regional precipitation projections under SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-8.5. Same format as Fig. 4 but for precipitation trends.
Attribution of historical temperature trends (1981–2020) to anthropogenic forcing. Each bar shows the median and range from emulator estimates using different ESMs and observational constraints.
Global and regional sources of uncertainty in future projections. Decomposition of total uncertainty into model, internal variability, and scenario components for 2050 and 2100.
Spatial patterns of temperature and precipitation change by 2100 under SSP5-8.5. Maps show emulator ensemble mean projections of surface air temperature and precipitation anomalies.

Percentage of time during the decade when air temperature exceeds 25 °C by end-of-century (2091–2100) under SSP5-8.5 scenario. This panel shows the projected proportion of time during which Tair exceeds 25 °C, indicating potentially critical heat exposure frequency across different global regions. Darker shades represent a higher percentage of time spent above this temperature threshold, highlighting regions where populations will face the greatest challenges related to heat stress and reduced liveability.

Global map of linear trends in winter-mean (December–February) temperatures based on ERA5. Units are °C per 27 years. Two boxed regions (East Asia and North America) indicate areas used in panels b and c of the figure. The global mean temperature (right axis) is shown as a reference.

Relative change in decadal variability of surface air temperature over land (red–blue shading; variance ratio of 11-year running mean winter temperatures in ramp-up experiments vs. pre-industrial (PI) control). Values greater than 1 indicate increased decadal variability; values less than 1 indicate decreased variability. Purple-brown shading shows SST trends in the ramp-up experiment. Crosses mark statistically significant areas (95% confidence level).

Sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies (°C) during the Last Interglacial (LIG) relative to preindustrial (PI) for the SL4.1 simulation. The SL4.1 scenario applies Antarctic ice sheet melt consistent with sea level reconstructions. Circles and squares denote marine proxy data for SST. Solid lines indicate winter (black) and summer (green) sea ice extent.

SST anomalies for the LIG period relative to PI for the SL7.1 scenario, featuring a larger Antarctic ice sheet contribution. Proxy SST markers and sea ice extent lines are overlaid, showing enhanced warming in the high southern latitudes.

SST anomaly map for the FW7.1 simulation representing freshwater forcing from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS). Blue anomalies dominate the Southern Ocean, suggesting strong cooling in response to freshwater fluxes, with proxy SST data shown for comparison.

SST anomalies from the FW4.1 freshwater hosing scenario, indicating cooling around the Antarctic margin. This setup reflects intermediate freshwater input and its suppressive effects on Southern Ocean warming.

Combined freshwater and sea-level forcing scenario COMB4.1, illustrating SST anomalies during the LIG. Cooling prevails in the Southern Ocean, aligning with paleoclimate SST reconstructions in several sectors.

SST anomalies in the COMB7.1 simulation, combining both strong freshwater input and higher sea-level contributions. Cooling patterns intensify west of Antarctica and in the South Pacific, consistent with proxy data.

Ensemble of SST anomaly maps for six LIG simulations (SL4.1, FW4.1, COMB4.1, SL7.1, FW7.1, COMB7.1), each relative to PI. Proxy data symbols and modeled sea ice boundaries are included to assess model-proxy agreement across different ice melt and freshwater forcing scenarios.

Surface air temperature (SAT) anomalies (°C) during austral summer (DJF) in six LIG simulations relative to PI. Patterns reflect the climatic response to varying Antarctic meltwater and sea-level scenarios. Circles denote Antarctic ice core temperature reconstructions for comparison.

Infant mortality burden associated with ood exposures in Africa (2000–2020). The results were presented as excess deaths per 1000 liveborn births associated with 5-year average ood events, and illustrated in map

Shading shows near-surface atmospheric temperature (K) from ERA-Interim, and contours show sea-level pressure (SLP) anomalies with a 0.5 hPa interval, solid for positive and dashed for negative values.
The homogeneous maps capture the WACE (Warm Arctic–Cold Eurasia) dipole pattern and associated SLP anomalies, resembling results from Mori et al. (2019).
Heterogeneous regression map showing near-surface temperature (K) anomalies from ERA-Interim regressed on the AMIP expansion coefficients. The WACE pattern is present but with reduced amplitude.

Heterogeneous regression map of near-surface temperature (K) from AMIP regressed on the ERAI expansion coefficients. The cold anomaly over Eurasia is weakened and displaced southward; the Siberian anticyclone is absent.

This map shows the level of warming (°C) from 1991–2018 due to human-induced climate change across 732 cities in 43 countries. Higher levels of warming are evident in parts of South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia, with some areas exceeding +2°C. Data derived from comparisons between factual (with anthropogenic forcings) and counterfactual (natural forcings only) climate scenarios ￼.

Global heat-mortality risk associated with warming. Each dot represents the relative risk of heat-related mortality for 732 cities worldwide, based on epidemiological exposure-response functions. Redder areas signify greater health risks from extreme heat, with Europe and East Asia showing high relative risks due to recent warming trends

Heat-related mortality rate attributable to anthropogenic climate change. This choropleth map presents the country-level burden of mortality (per 100,000 population) from human-induced warming between 1991–2018. Countries in South America, Southern Europe, and Southeast Asia experienced the highest mortality rates, emphasizing the severe public health implications of global warming

Change in climate damage projections from including variability and extremes. This map shows how including precipitation variability, wet days, and extreme events alters GDP loss projections at +3°C warming. Most countries, especially in the Global South, experience greater economic losses when such factors are considered, highlighting the underestimated burden under the “annual temperature only” status quo approach

Global GDP loss at +3°C warming under extended climate damage modeling. GDP losses as a percentage of national income are shown globally, using an approach that includes both mean annual temperature and indicators of climate variability and extremes. Losses are especially severe in low-latitude and low-income countries, where exposure and vulnerability are high

Exposure of global population to tail risks of GDP loss due to climate change. The figure shows the percentage of the global population facing at least a 5% chance of economic damage exceeding various thresholds at different warming levels. Including all climate indicators increases the estimated population share exposed to catastrophic losses (e.g., >15%) compared to traditional models using only annual temperature

Rate of surface air temperature change (°C per decade) across the Arctic region from 1979 to 2021. The map highlights particularly intense warming over the Barents Sea, East Siberian Sea, and Chukchi Sea regions, based on observational datasets. Warming rates exceed 2.5°C per decade in key regions, consistent with patterns of Arctic amplification.

Difference in the rate of surface air temperature change (°C per decade) between Barents/Kara Seas and Greenland/Canada sectors from 1979 to 2021. Positive (red) values indicate regions warming faster than the mean Arctic rate, while negative (blue) values indicate slower warming. This panel demonstrates the east–west contrast in Arctic amplification patterns, especially pronounced around Svalbard and Greenland.
Projected sea-ice concentration changes (rows a–h) and surface shortwave radiation changes (rows i–p) over the Barents and Kara Seas under SSP5-8.5 scenario for future decades (2030s to 2090s).

Global map of average SST anomaly memory (τ) from 1982–2023, in days. Longest memory (>20 days) occurs in the eastern Pacific and mid-latitude oceans; shortest (<10 days) in the equatorial west Pacific and Southern Ocean.
Trend in SST memory (days per decade) from 1982–2023. Most regions show increasing τ, meaning SST anomalies persist longer. Dots indicate statistically significant trends.
Global map showing the warming level (°C above pre-industrial) at which lake surface temperatures exceed historical natural variability.
Spatial distribution of projected trends in lake surface temperature from 2000 to 2100, measured in °C per decade.
Map of natural variability in lake surface temperature from the historical period (1850–1900), measured as °C.
Warming threshold (°C) for bottom water temperatures to exceed historical variability, with black indicating no emergence this century.
Spatial pattern of bottom temperature change (2000–2100) during the warm season, in °C per decade.
Estimated historical variability in bottom water temperature (1850–1900), shown in °C.
Percentage of days with full water column overturning during the warm season (1850–1900), affecting heat transfer to lake depths.

Panels a–d show the percent change in the variance explained by the lag 10-day autocorrelation (r²₁₀) of surface temperature between the Historical period (1970–1999) and the Future period (2070–2099) for four Earth System Models: a) NCAR CESM1 b) CSIRO Mk3.6 c) CCCma CanESM2 d) GFDL ESM2M Warm colors indicate increased persistence, cool colors decreased persistence. Stippling marks areas where ≥75% of ensemble members agree on the sign of change and results exceed the 95% significance level.

Panels a–c show the same change in r²₁₀ as above but averaged across all four ESMs (150 members total) and viewed from different projections: a) Arctic b) Global view c) Antarctic Stippling highlights statistically significant and consistent changes across at least 3 out of 4 models

Flood-safe versus flood-exposed growth: relative difference between settlement growth in safe and high-hazard areas from 1985 to 2015. In red areas, the share of flood-exposed settlements is increasing, that is, settlements in high-hazard flood zones have expanded at least 50% more than settlements in flood-safe areas. In blue areas, flood exposure is decreasing.

Regional temperature differences (NorESM2-LM) between overshoot and stabilization scenarios, averaged over 100 years of global temperature stabilization. Hatched areas show statistically significant differences compared to internal variability.

Multi-model ensemble differences in regional temperature before and after overshoot. Models show temperature anomalies for 31-year periods at 0.2 °C below peak warming in SSP5-34-OS and SSP1-19. Hatching denotes significance; stippling shows agreement across at least 66% of models.
Regional temperature differences (GFDL-ESM2M) between overshoot and stabilization scenarios, similar to Fig. 3e. Highlights delayed warming in the North Atlantic due to AMOC recovery after overshoot.
Summer 2022 temperature anomalies (in °C) across European regions relative to baseline values, showing widespread above-average temperatures, especially in southwestern Europe.
Heat-related mortality rates per million population for all ages and both sexes combined during summer 2022, with highest values observed in southern Europe, particularly Spain, Italy, and Greece.
Heat-related mortality among women aged 65–79 years across Europe during summer 2022. Elevated risk is concentrated in southeastern and southwestern regions.
Mortality rates per million for individuals aged 80 and above (both sexes) during the summer 2022 heatwave, highlighting extreme impacts in Greece, Spain, and Italy.
Heat-related mortality rates for women of all ages during summer 2022, showing a strong gradient from central/northern Europe to southern Europe, with the highest burdens in Greece and Spain.
Mortality rates attributed to heat among men of all ages during summer 2022. Southern Europe shows the highest impact, although spatial variation is somewhat less than among women.
Heat-related deaths per million among men aged 65–79 years across European regions during summer 2022, with notable clusters in southern Europe.
Summer 2022 heat-related mortality for men aged 80+, indicating particularly high death rates in southern Spain, southern Italy, and parts of the Balkans.

a, Average regional temperature anomalies (in °C) across Europe during the 14-week summer period (30 May–4 September 2022). b–f, Regional heat-related mortality rates (deaths per million people) for: b) the total population, c) women aged 65–79, d) men aged 65–79, e) women aged 80 and older,     f, men aged 80 and older. This figure highlights the spatial distribution of heat impacts across demographic groups during Europe’s hottest summer on record.

Annual mean (a,b) and 95th percentile (c,d) values of the Ta biases (°C) in the raw (a,c) and bias-corrected (b,d) climate model simulations over the period 1991–2020. The raw simulations show large positive and negative biases in many regions. The bias-correction approach drastically reduces these biases for both annual means and extremes.

Annual mean (a,b) and 95th percentile (c,d) values of the Tw biases (°C) in the raw (a,c) and bias-corrected (b,d) simulations. The raw simulations show strong negative biases in the tropics and mid-latitudes, which are substantially corrected by the bias-adjustment procedure, especially in areas of high population exposure.

Annual mean (a,b) and 95th percentile (c,d) values of the WBGT biases (°C) in the raw (a,c) and bias-corrected (b,d) simulations. Raw WBGT simulations exhibit widespread cold biases, which are largely corrected after bias adjustment, improving the consistency of WBGT for health assessments.

Mean annual wet-bulb temperature (°C) for the reference period 1991–2020. The map also highlights key hotspot regions (e.g., Amazon, Sahel, North China Plain, etc.) used in the study to assess heat-related mortality risks and future projections under climate change.

Sea Surface Temperature (SST) Variability and Marine Heatwave Changes. Comparison of historical SST variance (a–b) and projected changes (c–f) between 1960–2000 and 2060–2100. Highlights include spatial patterns of SST variance, standard deviation, and intensifying marine heatwaves. Stippling shows regions without statistically significant changes.

Observed Parameters of the Stochastic SST Model (HadISST). Annual-mean ocean memory (a), ENSO teleconnection strength (b), and stochastic noise forcing (c), derived from observations and reanalysis products, characterizing physical SST variability drivers in the North Pacific.

CESM2-LE Simulated Parameters for 1960–2000. Ensemble mean of ocean memory (d), ENSO teleconnection pattern (e), and stochastic noise forcing (f), showing key model-simulated variability drivers. Stippling indicates areas where model and observations differ significantly.

Projected Changes to SST Variability Drivers by 2100. CESM2-LE projections of future ocean memory (g), ENSO teleconnections (h), and noise forcing (i), averaged over the seasonal cycle. Changes reveal potential northeastward ENSO pattern shift and intensification of noise forcing.

Projected Shifts in Physical Drivers of SST Variability. Changes in ocean memory (j), ENSO teleconnection strength (k), and stochastic noise variance (l) between 1960–2000 and 2060–2100. Stippling shows regions where changes are statistically insignificant.

Observed and Simulated SST Feedback Mechanisms. Turbulent, radiative, and residual SST feedbacks from HadISST (a–c) and CESM2-LE (d–f). Highlights the role of air-sea fluxes and ocean-atmosphere coupling in driving SST damping and variability.

Future Changes to SST Feedbacks and Ocean Heat Capacity. CESM2-LE projected changes in turbulent (g), radiative (h), and residual feedbacks (i), along with mixed layer depth contribution to feedback changes (j). These factors help explain spatial patterns in future SST memory and variance.

Amplification of Heatwaves Due to Urbanization. Spatial patterns and regional comparisons of compound heatwave frequency differences between urban and rural areas from 2003–2019. Panels show global distribution (a), high (c), and low urbanization areas (e), with corresponding North–South comparisons (b, d, f). Amplification is stronger in Global North and highly urbanized cities.

Impact of Urban Warming on Exposure Inequality. Differences in heat exposure index (HEI) between real (with urban warming) and hypothetical (without urban warming) scenarios. Global maps (a), bar plots by region (b), and latitudinal trends (c) show that urbanization-induced warming narrows Global North–South disparities.

Independent Role of Urban Warming in Heat Exposure. Contribution of urbanization-induced warming to urban heat exposure, shown across all cities (a), high urbanization areas (c), and low urbanization areas (e). Regional breakdowns (b, d, f) reveal stronger impacts in Global North cities.

Global Patterns of Compound Heatwave Exposure. Spatial distribution of heat exposure levels across urban (a), high (c), and low urbanization areas (e), categorized using Jenks classification. Bar plots (b, d, f) indicate a higher share of high-risk cities in densely urbanized regions.

Projected spatial pattern of temperature sensitivity (%/°C) under the SSP5-8.5 scenario for the long-term future (2071–2099), showing how the total precipitation amount in extreme precipitation events (EPEs) responds to increases in global surface air temperature. Positive sensitivity dominates globally, with especially high values in western India, Southeast Asia, northern Africa, and the Americas. Negative sensitivity is observed in regions like Central America, southern Africa, and the Mediterranean.

Spatial distribution of the projected temperature sensitivity of extreme precipitation events (EPE-Hs) under the SSP5–8.5 scenario in the long-term future (2071–2099). High positive sensitivities dominate across low-latitude regions, particularly in South Asia, Southeast Asia, central Africa, and South America, indicating a sharp increase in precipitation during EPEs following heat stress.

Projected spatial distribution of temperature sensitivity for EPEs not preceded by heat stress (EPE-NHs). Negative sensitivities are observed across mid-latitude regions such as the Mediterranean, eastern South America, southern Africa, and Australia, suggesting reduced extreme precipitation response to warming where heat stress is absent.

(a) January to March (JFM), (b) April to June (AMJ), and (c) July to September (JAS). The fire season is defined as August to October (ASO). Diagonal lines indicate regions that are statistically significant at the 95% confidence interval. The green shading over the South American continent represents Cerrado north of 16°S, over which the annual BA was aggregated and used as a predictor in the regression analysis. The Niño3.4 and NTA regions are indicated by green boxes in (a)

This map displays 573 major flood disasters (dots) that occurred between 1990 and 2018, with the size of the dots indicating the number of reported flood fatalities, and the colour of the countries indicating their average level of income inequality across the sample. The flood disasters are reports from the Emergency Events Database (EM-DAT) that have been georeferenced to districts (or smaller subdivisions) using the Geocoded Disasters dataset (GDIS). Basemap from Natural Earth (https://www.naturalearthdata.com/)

Local Arctic amplification ratio (1979–2021).” Shows how much faster different regions warmed compared to the global mean. Some Arctic Ocean regions warmed up to 7 times faster than the global average, with values above 4 common across the Eurasian Arctic. The Arctic Circle is also indicated.

Shows how much faster different regions warmed compared to the global mean. Some Arctic Ocean regions warmed up to 7 times faster than the global average, with values above 4 common across the Eurasian Arctic. The Arctic Circle is also indicated.

The 20-year mean satellite-derived near-surface air temperature (T₂m^SAT) over sea ice (SIC > 15%) for the period 1995–2014. The red line indicates areas where observed sea ice concentration (SIC) is ≥ 70% (SIC70), averaged over the same period.

Panels show the mean difference between satellite-derived 2-meter air temperature (T₂m^SAT) and (b) ERA5 reanalysis (T₂m^ERA5) and (c) CMIP6 model ensemble (T₂m^CMIP6) over Arctic sea ice during 1995–2014. ERA5 exhibits a widespread warm bias, especially over central Arctic regions, whereas CMIP6 models align more closely with observations, generally showing smaller biases.

“Enhanced sensible heat fluxes driven by drought conditions.” Shows standardised anomalies of surface sensible heat flux, with values exceeding +3σ in northern Argentina, reflecting the influence of dry soils on atmospheric heating.
“Warmest summer on record across much of Argentina.” Ranks 2022/23 TX relative to all summers since 1950, with widespread areas recording their hottest warm season on record.

“Exceptional seasonal heat in Argentina during Nov 2022–Mar 2023.” Shows standardised anomalies of daily maximum temperature (TX), with central and northern Argentina experiencing up to +4σ above the 1981–2010 climatology.

“Persistent heatwave conditions across central Argentina.” Displays the proportion of warm-season days classified as heatwaves, with over 40% of days meeting heatwave criteria in many central regions.

“High-impact heatwave event in early December 2022.” Highlights the relative frequency of heatwave days during the Pacific Anticyclone Heatwave (PAHW), with central-northern Argentina showing over 90% heatwave occurrence in this period.

Shows ERA5-based trend in the annual maximum of daily maximum temperatures, scaled per degree of global warming. Northern France and Benelux exhibit the most rapid warming (>5 °C/GWD), highlighting a regional heat amplification hotspot.

Estimated using a circulation-analogue approach, this map isolates the warming component due to changes in atmospheric dynamics alone. Highlights a significant but smaller contribution (~1.5 °C/GWD) in Western Europe.
Depicts the trend in seasonal average TX, showing broader but slightly weaker warming (~2–3 °C/GWD) than TXx. Elevated trends are centered over France and the Iberian Peninsula.
Like TXx, circulation changes also explain a portion of the TXm trend. This map shows that increased prevalence of warm flow patterns accounts for up to ~1 °C/GWD in parts of Western Europe.

Anomaly map at 500 hPa for 29 June 2019, representative of the dominant pattern associated with extreme heat in central France. The ridge-trough setup promotes hot, dry air advection from the south. This flow type—“SF pattern”—has become more frequent and persistent, amplifying regional heat extremes.

Total number of years (out of 37) during which each location was classified under its dominant Köppen-Geiger climate class. This map highlights regions with high interannual classification consistency (e.g., the Arctic and deserts) versus transitional zones with more variability.

Agreement among 32 CMIP5 climate model projections on future shifts in Köppen-Geiger classification. Blue areas show strong agreement on future changes, while red areas reflect low consensus — especially in tropical and subtropical regions.

Comparison of the spatial distribution (left two panels) and the difference (right panel) between the observation and HAPPI hist simulations. The white dots in the right panel represent the area where 80% of the used AGCMs agree with the change sign.

“Average relative risk of heatstroke deaths, 2008–2019.” Shows the spatial distribution of relative risk estimates by prefecture across Japan, highlighting elevated risk in regions such as Kinki, Shikoku, and Tohoku, and lower risk in Hokkaido.

“Average temperature anomaly (June–August, 2008–2019) by prefecture.” Displays long-term summer temperature anomalies, with the Tohoku region showing notably higher-than-average warming relative to the 1980–2010 baseline.

Average percentage of elderly population by prefecture (2008–2019).” Shows spatial variation in population aging across Japan, with rural regions such as Tohoku and Shikoku having higher concentrations of elderly residents.

“Posterior mean of spatio-temporal interaction (2008–2019).” Estimates the deviation of prefecture-specific heatstroke mortality trends from the national average trend. Red-shaded prefectures show faster increases in risk over time.

“Posterior probability of spatio-temporal interaction (2008–2019).” Shows statistical confidence in the trends from Figure 4a. Blue/purple areas indicate low certainty in trend deviations, while red areas reflect higher probability of significant local trend change.

Different types of urbanization effect (UE) for the six drought metrics using a 100 km urban–rural buffer threshold. Blue, orange and red bars represent the stations and/or cities with statistically significant negative UE, statistically significant positive UE and insignificant UE, respectively

Global distribution of peak point temperatures for the precipitation–temperature (PT) scaling curve (left) and streamflow–temperature (QT) scaling curve (right) across 7,239 catchments. These peak points represent the temperature at which extreme precipitation or streamflow events reach their maximum intensity.

Comparison of peak temperatures from the PT and QT scaling curves for catchments dominated by four different flood types: intense rainfall-induced (IR-MF), excessive soil moisture-induced (ES-MF), snowmelt-induced (SM-MF), and rain-on-snow-induced (RS-MF). Panels show correlation strength between the two peak points depending on the dominance of each flood type.

Regional glacier mass changes from 2000 to 2019 across 19 RGI regions. Disk areas represent mass loss, split by land- (grey) and marine-terminating (blue) glaciers. Annual elevation change rates and data coverage are shown in time bars below each disk. Regions 2, 5, 9, and 17 are further divided to highlight regional contrasts.

Mean glacier elevation change rates from 2000 to 2019, shown for tiles scaled by glacierized area. Tile size and shape vary by latitude to represent ~10,000 km². Color indicates elevation change; grey marks low data coverage or high uncertainty.

Comparison to previous global estimates. Regional and global specific-mass change rates with 95% confidence intervals. a, Estimates from earlier studies5,19–21 (coloured) and from this study (black) over the corresponding time periods. b, Global estimates from earlier studies, and annual and 5-year rates from this study. Annual rates from earlier studies are not shown owing to large uncertainties. Uncertainties from this study are conservative, in particular for regions with most negative specific rates
